   phos, so cholecystitis less likely.  Could also be due to pneumonia or
   due to PICC line infection (PICC has been removed)
   - per ID, now on Vancomycin/Cipro: Day 1 [**12-3**] of Vanc and added Cipro
   [**12-4**].  If decompensates, Meropenem appropriate.  Plan to continue cipro
   x 3-4 weeks, vanco for 6 weeks (start [**11-14**])
   - will send sputum Cx today (prior Cx
s have been poor samples)
   - f/u culture urine, blood, sputum, and gall bladder drainage
   - Vanc trough elevated this AM, but drawn early; will repeat a PM vanc
   trough
   -will transfuse 1u PRBCs this AM given continued hypotension and anemia
   -gentle IV fluid boluses to mainatain UOP and MAP > 60
   # Respiratory Failure:  Likely secondary to infectious process.
   Empiric therapy for HAP as above. Was on trach mask at facility.
   Barriers to extubation currently include muscle weakness, altered
   mental status and pulmonary edema.
   - Yesterday was on put on trach mask and did well, will try again today
   - Speech consult pending
   - Continue combivent
   - Continue gentle diuresis with Lasix as needed, goal I/O negative ~1L
   - PM I/O check
   .
   # Cold lower extremities, Left > right; Pt does have a hx of venous
   clotting, although currently on heparin and coumadin.
   - LE ultrasound with dopplers to assess venous and arterial patency
   .
   # Altered mental status and h/o Seizures and Likely Anoxic Cerebral
   Injury:  No current evidence of seizure activity but he does have a
   history of non-convulsive status epilepticus.  EEG neg for seizure so
   likely due to hypotension, possibly oversedation from anti-epileptic
   medications.
   - appreciate neurology input; will stop Phenobarbital today with plan
   to stop keppra next (per neuro recs)
   - continue phenytoin and keppra for now
   .
   # Hematuria and BPH:  Was described at rehab [**12-2**], now present.
   Patient was followed by urology during recent hospital stay and was
   started on flomax.  Continues to have some hematuria, has 3 way foley
   and undergoing bladder irrigation.  Likely due to anticoagulation in
   the setting of foley placements.
   - cont flomax
   - continue Foley with bladder irrigation
   .
   # Anemia:  Hct stable.  Note that patient required multiple
   transfusions during recent hospital stay and he has guaiac positive
   stool as well as recent hematuria.
   - check Hct daily
   - active T&S
   - ranitidine for guaiac positive stool
   - transfuse 1 u PRBCs today
   # Recent Cholecystitis:   As above this may be contributing to the
   patient's septic picture.  Abdominal exam and LFTs somewhat
   reassuring.  Gen [**Doctor First Name 458**] states perc tube in place.
   -ask IR when tube to be removed.
   # S/p Aortic arch repair/dissection/CABG:  Long, complicated course
   following the procedure.  CT surgery consulted in the ED.  Recently had
   TEE that did not show vegetations on grafts or pacemaker leads, but at
   risk for endovascular seeding, particularly if blood cultures come back
   positive.
   - follow any CT [**Doctor First Name 458**] recs
   - Continue simvastatin and ASA
   # Elevated troponin and EKG changes: Suspect patient was somewhat
   ischemic in setting of hypotension and tachycardia.
   - continue ASA
   # Acute renal failure: Now creatinine stable at 1.0
   - follow urine output
   - renally dose meds (vancomycin)

   - Continue gentle diuresis as above

   - restarted coumadin at home dose, INR now subtherapeutic
   - heparin gtt to bridge
   # Infiltrated IV site:  plastics said no compartment syndrome, appears

   Assessment and Plan
   76yo gentleman who is s/p redo replacement aortic arch with presumed
   anoxic brain injury and post-op bacteremia as well as cholecystitis s/p
   cholecystosomy admitted for sepsis, found to have serratia bacteremia.
   # Septic shock/ serratia: With serratia bacteremia, most likely source
   of sepsis is GI vs urine, although UA on admission was not impressive
   (although was after antibioitics).  LFTs were normal apart from alk
   phos, so cholecystitis less likely.  Could also be due to pneumonia or
   due to PICC line infection (PICC has been removed)
   - per ID, now on Vancomycin/Cipro: Day 1 [**12-3**] of Vanc and added Cipro
   [**12-4**].  If decompensates, Meropenem appropriate.  Plan to continue cipro
   x 3-4 weeks, vanco for 6 weeks (start [**11-14**])
   - will send sputum Cx today (prior Cx
s have been poor samples)
   - f/u culture urine, blood, sputum, and gall bladder drainage
   - Vanc trough elevated this AM, but drawn early; will repeat a PM vanc
   trough
   -will transfuse 1u PRBCs this AM given continued hypotension and anemia
   -gentle IV fluid boluses to mainatain UOP and MAP > 60
   # Respiratory Failure:  Likely secondary to infectious process.
   Empiric therapy for HAP as above. Was on trach mask at facility.
   Barriers to extubation currently include muscle weakness, altered
   mental status and pulmonary edema.
   - Yesterday was on put on trach mask and did well, will try again today
   - Speech consult pending
   - Continue combivent
   - Continue gentle diuresis with Lasix as needed, goal I/O negative ~1L
   - PM I/O check
   .
   # Cold lower extremities, Left > right; Pt does have a hx of venous
   clotting, although currently on heparin and coumadin.
   - LE ultrasound with dopplers to assess venous and arterial patency
   .
   # Altered mental status and h/o Seizures and Likely Anoxic Cerebral
   Injury:  No current evidence of seizure activity but he does have a
   history of non-convulsive status epilepticus.  EEG neg for seizure so
   likely due to hypotension, possibly oversedation from anti-epileptic
   medications.
   - appreciate neurology input; will stop Phenobarbital today with plan
   to stop keppra next (per neuro recs)
   - continue phenytoin and keppra for now
   .
   # Hematuria and BPH:  Was described at rehab [**12-2**], now present.
   Patient was followed by urology during recent hospital stay and was
   started on flomax.  Continues to have some hematuria, has 3 way foley
   and undergoing bladder irrigation.  Likely due to anticoagulation in
   the setting of foley placements.
   - cont flomax
   - continue Foley with bladder irrigation
   .
   # Anemia:  Hct stable.  Note that patient required multiple
   transfusions during recent hospital stay and he has guaiac positive
   stool as well as recent hematuria.
   - check Hct daily
   - active T&S
   - ranitidine for guaiac positive stool
   - transfuse 1 u PRBCs today
   # Recent Cholecystitis:   As above this may be contributing to the
   patient's septic picture.  Abdominal exam and LFTs somewhat
   reassuring.  Gen [**Doctor First Name 458**] states perc tube in place.
   -ask IR when tube to be removed.
   # S/p Aortic arch repair/dissection/CABG:  Long, complicated course
   following the procedure.  CT surgery consulted in the ED.  Recently had
   TEE that did not show vegetations on grafts or pacemaker leads, but at
   risk for endovascular seeding, particularly if blood cultures come back
   positive.
   - follow any CT [**Doctor First Name 458**] recs
   - Continue simvastatin and ASA
   # Elevated troponin and EKG changes: Suspect patient was somewhat
   ischemic in setting of hypotension and tachycardia.
   - continue ASA
   # Acute renal failure: Now creatinine stable at 1.0
   - follow urine output
   - renally dose meds (vancomycin)
   # h/o diastolic heart failure:
   - Continue gentle diuresis as above
   # Atrial Fibrillation and UE DVTs:  INR now 1.8, restarted home
   metoprolol.
   - consider stopping dronederone as this is not keeping him in sinus
   (emailed cardiologist)
   - restarted coumadin at home dose, INR now subtherapeutic
   - heparin gtt to bridge
   # Infiltrated IV site:  plastics said no compartment syndrome, appears
   stable
   -heating compresses, elevate above heart
   # Hyperlipidemia:  continue statin
   ICU Care

Based on the patient's progress note, the following potential medical complications can arise:

1. Sepsis: The patient has a history of sepsis, and the current culture results show Serratia bacteremia. This can lead to further organ dysfunction and mortality.
2. Respiratory Failure: The patient's respiratory status is unstable, and he is at risk of developing further respiratory failure, particularly if he does not respond to empiric therapy for HAP.
3. Anoxic Brain Injury: The patient has a history of anoxic brain injury, and his altered mental status may be a result of this injury or hypotension.
4. Hematuria: The patient has ongoing hematuria, which can lead to further bleeding complications and potential kidney damage.
5. Anemia: The patient's anemia is likely due to blood loss and may require further transfusions.
6. Cholecystitis: The patient's recent cholecystitis may be contributing to his septic picture, and further management is needed to prevent complications.
7. Endovascular Seeding: The patient is at risk for endovascular seeding, particularly if blood cultures come back positive, which can lead to further complications.
8. Acute Renal Failure: The patient's creatinine is stable at 1.0, but further monitoring is needed to prevent further kidney damage.
9. Atrial Fibrillation: The patient's atrial fibrillation may be contributing to his tachycardia and potential ischemia.
10. Deep Vein Thrombosis (DVT): The patient has a history of DVT, and further monitoring is needed to prevent further clotting.
11. Infiltrated IV Site: The patient's infiltrated IV site may lead to further complications, such as compartment syndrome, if not managed properly.
12. Hyperlipidemia: The patient's hyperlipidemia may require further management to prevent cardiovascular complications.

The patient's current treatment plan includes:

1. Antibiotics: The patient is receiving antibiotics for Serratia bacteremia, and further management is needed to prevent further sepsis.
2. Respiratory Support: The patient is receiving respiratory support, and further management is needed to prevent further respiratory failure.
3. Diuresis: The patient is receiving diuresis to manage his fluid status and prevent further complications.
4. Blood Transfusions: The patient is receiving blood transfusions to manage his anemia and potential bleeding complications.
5. Medication Management: The patient is receiving medications to manage his atrial fibrillation, hyperlipidemia, and potential bleeding complications.

The patient's current status is stable, but further monitoring is needed to prevent further complications.

Based on the patient's progress note, the following summary and potential medical complications can be identified:

Summary:

The patient is a 76-year-old male with a complex medical history, including aortic replacement, prolonged hospitalization, and recurrent infections. He is currently in the ICU with sepsis, respiratory failure, and altered mental status. He is ventilator-dependent and has a left pleural effusion and pulmonary edema. He has a history of chronic anemia, atrial fibrillation, and dyslipidemia.

Potential Medical Complications:

1. Sepsis: The patient's sepsis is severe, and there is a risk of progression to septic shock and organ failure.
2. Respiratory Failure: The patient's respiratory failure is acute and may worsen if not managed properly. There is a risk of ventilator-associated pneumonia (VAP) and respiratory acidosis.
3. Altered Mental Status: The patient's altered mental status may be due to sepsis, medication, or other underlying conditions. There is a risk of delirium and decreased level of consciousness.
4. Pulmonary Edema: The patient's pulmonary edema may worsen if not managed properly, leading to respiratory failure and cardiac complications.
5. Left Pleural Effusion: The patient's left pleural effusion may worsen if not managed properly, leading to respiratory compromise and cardiac complications.
6. Aortic Dissection: The patient's history of aortic dissection is a significant risk factor for cardiac complications, including aortic rupture and cardiac tamponade.
7. Heart Failure: The patient's chronic heart failure may worsen if not managed properly, leading to cardiac complications and decreased cardiac output.
8. Anemia: The patient's chronic anemia may worsen if not managed properly, leading to decreased oxygen delivery to tissues and organs.
9. Dyslipidemia: The patient's dyslipidemia may worsen if not managed properly, leading to increased risk of cardiovascular complications.
10. Infection: The patient's history of recurrent infections may increase the risk of further infections, including hospital-acquired infections such as VAP and central line-associated bloodstream infections (CLABSIs).

Given the patient's complex medical history and current condition, it is essential to closely monitor his vital signs, laboratory results, and respiratory and cardiovascular function. Additionally, it is crucial to manage his sepsis, respiratory failure, and altered mental status effectively to prevent further complications.

Based on the provided progress note, I summarize the patient's health progress as follows:

The patient is a 76-year-old male who has undergone a complex recent medical history, including a redo replacement of the ascending aorta and arch with a graft, complicated by recurrent infection, respiratory failure, cholecystitis with percutaneous drainage, and substantial peripheral muscle weakness. He is currently readmitted with sepsis and Serratia growing in his blood culture.

The patient's major active issues include:

1. Improving sepsis, with mobilizing fluids and negative fluid balance over the previous two days.
2. Ventilator dependence due to weakness.
3. Altered mental status, with improved consciousness.
4. Left pleural effusion and pulmonary edema.

The patient's laboratory results show:

1. Hemoglobin: 8.5 g/dL
2. White Blood Cell Count: 6.1 K/uL
3. Platelet Count: 183 K/uL
4. Creatinine: 1.1 mg/dL
5. Glucose: 83 mg/dL
6. Albumin: 3.2 g/dL
7. Calcium: 8.4 mg/dL
8. Magnesium: 1.5 mg/dL
9. Phosphate: 3.2 mg/dL

The patient is receiving various medications, including:

1. Antibiotics: Cefipime, Vancomycin, and Ciprofloxacin
2. Heparin Sodium
3. Furosemide (Lasix)
4. Morphine Sulfate
5. Famotidine (Pepcid)
6. Keppra, Phenobarb, and Dilantin for seizure prophylaxis

Potential medical complications that can arise from the patient's condition include:

1. Sepsis-related organ dysfunction
2. Respiratory failure
3. Pulmonary edema
4. Left pleural effusion
5. Cholecystitis with percutaneous drainage
6. Peripheral muscle weakness
7. Anoxic brain injury
8. Status epilepticus
9. Atrial fibrillation
10. DVT and LSC/RIJ thrombi

The patient's plan of care includes:

1. Continuing Vancomycin for 6 weeks
2. Ciprofloxacin for 2 weeks for Serratia
3. Moving to diuresis today at 1-2 liters per day as possible
4. Trial on tracheostomy mask and positive end-expiratory pressure (PEEP)
5. Continuing diuresis
6. Gradually stopping antiepileptics and EEG monitoring
7. USG vascular flow examination for cold left foot
8. Recheck LFTs for cholecystitis
9. Continue prophylaxis for DVT and stress ulcer
10. Monitor for VAP and adjust accordingly.

Summary:

The patient is a 76-year-old male with a complex medical history, including aortic replacement, sepsis, and respiratory failure. He is currently intubated and ventilator-dependent due to profound weakness. He has a left pleural effusion and pulmonary edema. His sepsis is improving, but he remains off pressors. He has a tracheostomy and is receiving antibiotics for Serratia infection.

The patient's vital signs are stable, with a temperature of 36C, heart rate of 62 bpm, and blood pressure of 85/42 mmHg. His respiratory rate is 21 breaths per minute, and his oxygen saturation is 100% on 40% FiO2. His laboratory results show elevated white blood cell count, lactate acid, and troponin-T, but normal electrolyte levels.

The patient's physical examination reveals a well-nourished but somnolent appearance, with a tracheostomy site that is clean and without signs of infection. His cardiovascular examination shows a normal heart rate and rhythm, with a blood pressure that is slightly low. His respiratory examination shows rhonchorous breath sounds, and his abdominal examination reveals soft and non-tender abdomen with bowel sounds present.

Potential medical complications:

1. Pneumonia: The patient's tracheostomy and prolonged hospitalization make him at risk for developing pneumonia.
2. Sepsis: The patient's sepsis is improving, but he remains at risk for developing further complications, such as organ dysfunction or death.
3. Respiratory failure: The patient's respiratory failure is acute and may worsen if not managed properly.
4. Atrial fibrillation: The patient's atrial fibrillation may worsen if not managed properly, leading to further complications such as heart failure or stroke.
5. Cholecystitis: The patient's cholecystitis may worsen if not managed properly, leading to complications such as infection or pancreatitis.
6. Aortic dissection: The patient's aortic dissection is a high-risk condition that may worsen if not managed properly, leading to complications such as rupture or dissection.
7. Anoxic brain injury: The patient's anoxic brain injury may worsen if not managed properly, leading to further complications such as seizures or cognitive impairment.

Recommendations:

1. Continue antibiotics for Serratia infection.
2. Continue diuresis to manage fluid overload.
3. Trial tracheostomy mask and PMV if tolerated.
4. Continue anticonvulsants for seizure prophylaxis.
5. Repeat EEG to assess for ongoing seizure disorder.
6. Monitor for signs of pneumonia, such as fever, cough, and chest pain.
7. Monitor for signs of sepsis, such as fever, tachycardia, and hypotension.
8. Monitor for signs of respiratory failure, such as tachypnea, hypoxemia, and hypercapnia.
9. Monitor for signs of atrial fibrillation, such as palpitations, chest pain, and shortness of breath.
10. Monitor for signs of cholecystitis, such as abdominal pain, nausea, and vomiting.

   of sepsis is GI vs urine, although UA on admission was not impressive
   (although was after antibioitics).  LFTs were normal apart from alk
   phos, so cholecystitis less likely.  Could also be due to pneumonia or
   due to PICC line infection (PICC has been removed)

   [**12-4**].  If decompensates, Meropenem appropriate.  Plan to continue cipro
   x 3-4 weeks, vanco for 6 weeks (start [**11-14**])

   -PICC today
   # Respiratory Failure:  Likely secondary to infectious process.
   Empiric therapy for HAP as above. Was on trach mask at facility.
   Barriers to extubation currently include muscle weakness, altered
   mental status and pulmonary edema.
   - retry trache mask later today
   - Speech consult pending
   - Continue combivent
   - Continue gentle diuresis with Lasix as needed, goal I/O negative ~1L
   , eval in pm as already net negative 1L for day
   - PM I/O check
   .
   # Cold lower extremities, Left > right; Pt does have a hx of venous
   clotting, although currently on heparin and coumadin.
   -resolved
   .
   # Altered mental status and h/o Seizures and Likely Anoxic Cerebral
   Injury:  No current evidence of seizure activity but he does have a
   history of non-convulsive status epilepticus.  EEG neg for seizure so
   likely due to hypotension, possibly oversedation from anti-epileptic
   medications.
   - appreciate neurology input; stopped Phenobarbital [**12-8**] with plan to
   cont Keppra and Dilantin.
   .
   # Hematuria and BPH:  Was described at rehab [**12-2**], now present.
   Patient was followed by urology during recent hospital stay and was
   started on flomax.  Continued to have some hematuria during this
   hospitalization, has 3 way foley and undergoing bladder irrigation.
   Likely due to anticoagulation in the setting of foley placements.  Now
   resolved.  If recurrs, might consider urology consult
   - cont flomax
   - continue Foley, no bladder irrigation currently needed
   .
   # Anemia:  Hct stable, had 1U yesterday of prbc.  Note that patient
   required multiple transfusions during recent hospital stay and he has
   guaiac positive stool as well as recent hematuria.
   - check Hct daily
   - active T&S
   - ranitidine for guaiac positive stool
   # Recent Cholecystitis:   As above this may be contributing to the
   patient's septic picture.  Abdominal exam and LFTs somewhat
   reassuring.  Gen [**Doctor First Name 458**] states perc tube in place.
   -Per IR:  Pt needs cholangiogram to confirm that the cystic duct is
   patent and then has the tube capped.  At six weeks post insertion the
   patient typically has an elective cholecystectomy. The attending
   surgeon who was consulted at the time of the tube being inserted(Dr
   [**Last Name (STitle) **] should have the final say on future management however and I
   would suggest reconsulting her
   # S/p Aortic arch repair/dissection/CABG:  Long, complicated course
   following the procedure.  CT surgery consulted in the ED.  Recently had
   TEE that did not show vegetations on grafts or pacemaker leads, but at
   risk for endovascular seeding, particularly if blood cultures come back
   positive.
   - follow any CT [**Doctor First Name 458**] recs
   - Continue simvastatin and ASA
   # Elevated troponin and EKG changes: Suspect patient was somewhat
   ischemic in setting of hypotension and tachycardia.
   - continue ASA
   # Acute renal failure: increased to 1.3
   - follow urine output
   - renally dose meds (vancomycin)
   # h/o diastolic heart failure:
   - Continue gentle diuresis as above
   # Atrial Fibrillation and UE DVTs:  INR now 1.7, restarted home
   metoprolol.
   - consider stopping dronederone as this is not keeping him in sinus
   (emailed cardiologist)
   - restarted coumadin at home dose, INR now subtherapeutic
   - increase coumadin dose to 7.5

Summary:

The patient is a 76-year-old male who was admitted to the ICU with sepsis, presumed anoxic brain injury, and post-op bacteremia following a redo replacement aortic arch with aortic dissection. He has a history of chronic heart failure, atrial fibrillation, and hyperlipidemia. The patient's current condition is complicated by acute respiratory failure, acute kidney injury, and altered mental status.

Potential Medical Complications:

1. Sepsis: The patient's sepsis may worsen, leading to organ dysfunction and potential mortality.
2. Respiratory Failure: The patient's respiratory failure may progress, requiring mechanical ventilation and potentially leading to ventilator-associated pneumonia.
3. Acute Kidney Injury: The patient's acute kidney injury may worsen, requiring dialysis and potentially leading to chronic kidney disease.
4. Altered Mental Status: The patient's altered mental status may persist or worsen, potentially leading to delirium and increased risk of falls and other complications.
5. Cardiovascular Complications: The patient's history of chronic heart failure and atrial fibrillation increases his risk of cardiovascular complications, such as heart failure exacerbation, arrhythmias, and cardiac arrest.
6. Infection: The patient's bacteremia and pneumonia increase his risk of developing further infections, such as urinary tract infections and wound infections.
7. Bleeding Complications: The patient's anticoagulation therapy increases his risk of bleeding complications, such as gastrointestinal bleeding and intracranial hemorrhage.
8. Nutritional Deficiencies: The patient's malnutrition and gastrointestinal bleeding may lead to nutritional deficiencies, potentially exacerbating his underlying medical conditions.
9. Pressure Ulcers: The patient's immobility and altered mental status increase his risk of developing pressure ulcers.
10. Medication-Related Complications: The patient's complex medication regimen increases his risk of medication-related complications, such as interactions, side effects, and overdose.

Recommendations:

1. Continue to monitor the patient's vital signs and laboratory results closely to detect any changes in his condition.
2. Optimize his respiratory support and consider extubation once his respiratory function improves.
3. Monitor his urine output and adjust his fluid management accordingly to prevent fluid overload.
4. Continue to manage his altered mental status with sedation and pain control.
5. Monitor his cardiovascular status and adjust his anticoagulation therapy as needed to prevent bleeding complications.
6. Consider consulting a nutritionist to optimize the patient's nutritional support.
7. Monitor the patient's skin integrity and take measures to prevent pressure ulcers.
8. Review the patient's medication regimen with his healthcare team to identify potential interactions and side effects.

   76yo gentleman who is s/p redo replacement aortic arch with presumed
   anoxic brain injury and post-op bacteremia as well as cholecystitis s/p
   cholecystosomy admitted for sepsis, found to have serratia bacteremia.
   # Septic shock/ serratia: With serratia bacteremia, most likely source
   of sepsis is GI vs urine, although UA on admission was not impressive
   (although was after antibioitics).  LFTs were normal apart from alk
   phos, so cholecystitis less likely.  Could also be due to pneumonia or
   due to PICC line infection (PICC has been removed)
   - per ID, now on Vancomycin/Cipro: Day 1 [**12-3**] of Vanc and added Cipro
   [**12-4**].  If decompensates, Meropenem appropriate.  Plan to continue cipro
   x 3-4 weeks, vanco for 6 weeks (start [**11-14**])
   -hold next Vanc dose and check level
   - will send sputum Cx today (prior Cx
s have been poor samples)
   - f/u culture urine, blood
   - high vanc trough, hold next dose, repeat trough
   -will transfuse 1u PRBCs this AM given continued hypotension and anemia
   -gentle IV fluid boluses to mainatain UOP and MAP > 60
   -PICC today
   # Respiratory Failure:  Likely secondary to infectious process.
   Empiric therapy for HAP as above. Was on trach mask at facility.
   Barriers to extubation currently include muscle weakness, altered
   mental status and pulmonary edema.
   - Yesterday was on put on trach mask and did well, will try again today
   - Speech consult pending
   - Continue combivent
   - Continue gentle diuresis with Lasix as needed, goal I/O negative ~1L
   - PM I/O check
   .
   # Cold lower extremities, Left > right; Pt does have a hx of venous
   clotting, although currently on heparin and coumadin.
   - LE ultrasound with dopplers to assess venous and arterial patency
   .
   # Altered mental status and h/o Seizures and Likely Anoxic Cerebral
   Injury:  No current evidence of seizure activity but he does have a
   history of non-convulsive status epilepticus.  EEG neg for seizure so
   likely due to hypotension, possibly oversedation from anti-epileptic
   medications.
   - appreciate neurology input; stopped Phenobarbital [**12-8**] with plan to
   stop keppra next (per neuro recs)
   .
   # Hematuria and BPH:  Was described at rehab [**12-2**], now present.
   Patient was followed by urology during recent hospital stay and was
   started on flomax.  Continues to have some hematuria, has 3 way foley
   and undergoing bladder irrigation.  Likely due to anticoagulation in
   the setting of foley placements.
   - cont flomax
   - continue Foley with bladder irrigation
   -consult urology today
   .
   # Anemia:  Hct stable, had 1U yesterday of prbc.  Note that patient
   required multiple transfusions during recent hospital stay and he has
   guaiac positive stool as well as recent hematuria.
   - check Hct daily
   - active T&S
   - ranitidine for guaiac positive stool
   # Recent Cholecystitis:   As above this may be contributing to the
   patient's septic picture.  Abdominal exam and LFTs somewhat
   reassuring.  Gen [**Doctor First Name 458**] states perc tube in place.
   -Per IR:  Pt needs cholangiogram to confirm that the cystic duct is
   patent and then has the tube capped.  At six weeks post insertion the
   patient typically has an elective cholecystectomy. The attending
   surgeon who was consulted at the time of the tube being inserted(Dr
   [**Last Name (STitle) **] should have the final say on future management however and I
   would suggest reconsulting her
   # S/p Aortic arch repair/dissection/CABG:  Long, complicated course
   following the procedure.  CT surgery consulted in the ED.  Recently had
   TEE that did not show vegetations on grafts or pacemaker leads, but at
   risk for endovascular seeding, particularly if blood cultures come back
   positive.
   - follow any CT [**Doctor First Name 458**] recs
   - Continue simvastatin and ASA
   # Elevated troponin and EKG changes: Suspect patient was somewhat

   - continue ASA
   # Acute renal failure: increased to 1.3

Summary:

The patient is a 76-year-old male who was admitted to the ICU with septic shock, serratia bacteremia, and cholecystitis. He has a history of redo aortic arch replacement, anoxic brain injury, and post-op bacteremia. The patient is currently on vancomycin and ciprofloxacin, and is being treated for septic shock, respiratory failure, and altered mental status. He has a history of seizures, anoxic cerebral injury, and atrial fibrillation.

Potential Medical Complications:

1. Sepsis: The patient's sepsis is likely due to serratia bacteremia, and may worsen if not treated promptly and effectively.
2. Respiratory Failure: The patient's respiratory failure is likely secondary to the infectious process, and may require continued mechanical ventilation.
3. Altered Mental Status: The patient's altered mental status may be due to hypotension, oversedation from anti-epileptic medications, or anoxic cerebral injury.
4. Anemia: The patient's anemia may worsen if not treated with further blood transfusions.
5. Cholecystitis: The patient's cholecystitis may contribute to his septic picture, and may require further management.
6. Hematuria: The patient's hematuria may be due to anticoagulation in the setting of foley placements, and may require further evaluation and management.
7. Acute Renal Failure: The patient's acute renal failure may worsen if not treated promptly and effectively.
8. Atrial Fibrillation: The patient's atrial fibrillation may require further management, including anticoagulation therapy.
9. Venous Thromboembolism: The patient's history of UE DVTs and INR of 1.7 may increase his risk of venous thromboembolism.
10. Infiltrated IV Site: The patient's infiltrated IV site may require further management to prevent compartment syndrome.

Recommendations:

1. Continue treatment for septic shock, respiratory failure, and altered mental status.
2. Monitor the patient's anemia and consider further blood transfusions if necessary.
3. Manage the patient's cholecystitis and hematuria with further evaluation and treatment as necessary.
4. Monitor the patient's acute renal failure and consider further treatment if necessary.
5. Manage the patient's atrial fibrillation with anticoagulation therapy and consider further management if necessary.
6. Monitor the patient's venous thromboembolism risk and consider further treatment if necessary.
7. Manage the patient's infiltrated IV site to prevent compartment syndrome.

   - f/u culture urine, blood
   -try to avoid IVF as now volume overloaded
   -PICC today in IR
   -send new blood, urine, and sputum cx given new fever this AM
   -? Tap pleural effusion if fevers do not resolve after groin line
   pulled
   .
   # Respiratory Failure:  Likely secondary to infectious process.
   Empiric therapy for HAP as above. Was on trach mask at facility.
   Barriers to extubation currently include muscle weakness, altered
   mental status and pulmonary edema.
   - retry trache mask later today
   - Speech consult pending
   - Continue combivent
   - Continue gentle diuresis with Lasix as needed, goal I/O negative ~1L
   , eval in pm as already net negative 1L for day
   - PM I/O check
   .
   # Acute renal failure: increased to 1.3
   - follow urine output
   - renally dose meds (vancomycin)
   .
   # Altered mental status and h/o Seizures and Likely Anoxic Cerebral
   Injury:  No current evidence of seizure activity but he does have a
   history of non-convulsive status epilepticus.  EEG neg for seizure so
   likely due to hypotension, possibly oversedation from anti-epileptic
   medications.
   - appreciate neurology input; stopped Phenobarbital [**12-8**] with plan to

   -Dilantin level today
   .
   # Hematuria and BPH:  Was described at rehab [**12-2**], now present.
   Patient was followed by urology during recent hospital stay and was
   started on flomax.  Continued to have some hematuria during this
   hospitalization, has 3 way foley and undergoing bladder irrigation.
   Likely due to anticoagulation in the setting of foley placements.  Now
   resolved.  If recurrs, might consider urology consult
   - cont flomax
   - continue Foley, no bladder irrigation currently needed
   .
   # Anemia:  Hct stable, had 1U yesterday of prbc.  Note that patient
   required multiple transfusions during recent hospital stay and he has
   guaiac positive stool as well as recent hematuria.
   - check Hct daily
   - active T&S
   - ranitidine for guaiac positive stool
   .
   # Recent Cholecystitis:   As above this may be contributing to the
   patient's septic picture.  Abdominal exam and LFTs somewhat
   reassuring.  Gen [**Doctor First Name 458**] states perc tube in place.
   -Per IR:  Pt needs cholangiogram to confirm that the cystic duct is

   patient typically has an elective cholecystectomy. The attending

   .

   TEE that did not show vegetations on grafts or pacemaker leads, but at
   risk for endovascular seeding, particularly if blood cultures come back
   positive.
   - follow any CT [**Doctor First Name 458**] recs
   - Continue simvastatin and ASA
   .
   # Elevated troponin and EKG changes: Suspect patient was somewhat

   - continue ASA

   # h/o diastolic heart failure:

Summary:

The patient is a 76-year-old male admitted to the ICU with septic shock, presumed anoxic brain injury, and post-operative bacteremia. He has a history of aortic arch repair, CABG, and cholecystitis. He is currently receiving antibiotics for Serratia bacteremia, and his respiratory status is compromised due to pulmonary edema. He is also experiencing acute renal failure, altered mental status, and hematuria. He has a history of seizures and non-convulsive status epilepticus.

Potential Medical Complications:

1. Septic Shock: The patient's septic shock is likely due to Serratia bacteremia, and if not managed promptly, it can lead to organ dysfunction and death.
2. Respiratory Failure: The patient's respiratory status is compromised due to pulmonary edema, and if not managed effectively, it can lead to respiratory failure and death.
3. Acute Renal Failure: The patient's acute renal failure is likely due to septic shock and if not managed promptly, it can lead to chronic kidney disease and death.
4. Altered Mental Status: The patient's altered mental status is likely due to septic shock, hypotension, and oversedation from anti-epileptic medications, and if not managed promptly, it can lead to prolonged ICU stay and increased risk of complications.
5. Hematuria: The patient's hematuria is likely due to anticoagulation in the setting of Foley placements, and if not managed promptly, it can lead to bleeding complications and increased risk of infection.
6. Anemia: The patient's anemia is likely due to chronic blood loss and decreased production, and if not managed promptly, it can lead to decreased oxygen delivery to tissues and increased risk of complications.
7. Cholecystitis: The patient's cholecystitis may be contributing to his septic picture, and if not managed promptly, it can lead to further complications and increased risk of mortality.
8. Endovascular Seeding: The patient's history of aortic arch repair and CABG makes him at risk for endovascular seeding, particularly if blood cultures come back positive, and if not managed promptly, it can lead to further complications and increased risk of mortality.
9. Ischemic Complications: The patient's elevated troponin and EKG changes suggest ischemic complications, and if not managed promptly, it can lead to myocardial infarction and increased risk of mortality.
10. DVTs: The patient's history of UE DVTs and atrial fibrillation makes him at risk for further thrombotic complications, particularly if not managed promptly, it can lead to pulmonary embolism and increased risk of mortality.

Recommendations:

1. Continue antibiotics for Serratia bacteremia and monitor for signs of septic shock.
2. Manage respiratory status with gentle diuresis and continue combivent.
3. Monitor and manage acute renal failure with close attention to urine output and creatinine levels.
4. Continue anticonvulsant medications and monitor for signs of seizure activity.
5. Manage hematuria with close attention to Foley placements and anticoagulation therapy.
6. Monitor and manage anemia with close attention to hemoglobin levels and transfusion requirements.
7. Manage cholecystitis with close attention to abdominal exam and LFTs.
8. Monitor for signs of endovascular seeding and manage promptly if detected.
9. Manage ischemic complications with close attention to EKG changes and troponin levels.
10. Monitor for further thrombotic complications and manage promptly if detected.

Summary:

The patient is a 76-year-old male who underwent a redo replacement aortic arch with presumed anoxic brain injury and post-op bacteremia, followed by cholecystitis and sepsis. He has been admitted to the ICU for sepsis, respiratory failure, and acute renal failure. He has a history of seizures and anoxic cerebral injury. The patient's current condition is as follows:

* Respiratory: On ventilator support with a tracheostomy tube, with a recent tracheal trial that was unsuccessful due to dyspnea.
* Cardiovascular: In atrial fibrillation with a prolonged INR, and has a history of diastolic heart failure.
* Neurological: Has a history of seizures and anoxic cerebral injury, with altered mental status and low phenytoin level.
* Renal: Has acute renal failure with an increasing creatinine level, possibly related to recent dye load or hypotension.
* Hematological: Has anemia, with a stable Hct level, and has received multiple transfusions during recent hospital stay.
* Endocrine: Has hypercalcemia, with a corrected calcium level of 9.9.
* Gastrointestinal: Has a history of cholecystitis and is currently being managed with a GJ tube and perc choley.
* Infection: Has a positive blood culture for Serratia, and is being treated with vancomycin and ciprofloxacin.

Potential medical complications:

* Sepsis: The patient's sepsis may worsen, leading to further organ dysfunction and mortality.
* Respiratory failure: The patient's respiratory failure may progress, leading to further respiratory distress and potential respiratory arrest.
* Acute renal failure: The patient's acute renal failure may worsen, leading to further electrolyte imbalances and potential kidney failure.
* Hypercalcemia: The patient's hypercalcemia may worsen, leading to further electrolyte imbalances and potential cardiac arrhythmias.
* Anoxic cerebral injury: The patient's anoxic cerebral injury may worsen, leading to further neurological deficits and potential brain death.
* Infection: The patient's infection may spread to other areas of the body, leading to further organ dysfunction and mortality.
* Bleeding: The patient's bleeding risk is increased due to his anticoagulation therapy and recent surgical procedures.
* Gastrointestinal bleeding: The patient's gastrointestinal bleeding may worsen, leading to further bleeding and potential hemorrhagic shock.
* Cardiac arrhythmias: The patient's cardiac arrhythmias may worsen, leading to further cardiac instability and potential cardiac arrest.

   76yo gentleman who is s/p redo replacement aortic arch with presumed

   .

   of sepsis is GI vs urine, although UA on admission was not impressive
   (although was after antibioitics).  LFTs were normal apart from alk
   phos, so cholecystitis less likely.  Could also be due to pneumonia or
   due to PICC line infection (PICC has been removed)
   - per ID, now on Vancomycin/Cipro: Day 1 [**12-3**] of Vanc and added Cipro
   [**12-4**].  If decompensates, Meropenem appropriate.  Plan to continue cipro

   medications.
   - appreciate neurology input; stopped Phenobarbital [**12-8**] with plan to
   cont Keppra and Dilantin.
   -Dilantin level today
   .
   # Hematuria and BPH:  Was described at rehab [**12-2**], now present.
   Patient was followed by urology during recent hospital stay and was
   started on flomax.  Continued to have some hematuria during this
   hospitalization, has 3 way foley and undergoing bladder irrigation.
   Likely due to anticoagulation in the setting of foley placements.  Now
   resolved.  If recurrs, might consider urology consult
   - cont flomax
   - continue Foley, no bladder irrigation currently needed
   .
   # Anemia:  Hct stable, had 1U yesterday of prbc.  Note that patient
   required multiple transfusions during recent hospital stay and he has
   guaiac positive stool as well as recent hematuria.
   - check Hct daily
   - active T&S
   - ranitidine for guaiac positive stool
   .
   # Recent Cholecystitis:   As above this may be contributing to the
   patient's septic picture.  Abdominal exam and LFTs somewhat
   reassuring.  Gen [**Doctor First Name 458**] states perc tube in place.
   -Per IR:  Pt needs cholangiogram to confirm that the cystic duct is
   patent and then has the tube capped.  At six weeks post insertion the
   patient typically has an elective cholecystectomy. The attending
   surgeon who was consulted at the time of the tube being inserted(Dr
   [**Last Name (STitle) **] should have the final say on future management however and I
   would suggest reconsulting her
   .
   # S/p Aortic arch repair/dissection/CABG:  Long, complicated course
   following the procedure.  CT surgery consulted in the ED.  Recently had
   TEE that did not show vegetations on grafts or pacemaker leads, but at
   risk for endovascular seeding, particularly if blood cultures come back
   positive.
   - follow any CT [**Doctor First Name 458**] recs
   - Continue simvastatin and ASA
   .
   # Elevated troponin and EKG changes: Suspect patient was somewhat
   ischemic in setting of hypotension and tachycardia.
   - continue ASA
   .
   # h/o diastolic heart failure:
   - Continue gentle diuresis as above
   .
   # Atrial Fibrillation and UE DVTs:  INR now 2.2, restarted home
   metoprolol.
   - consider stopping dronederone as this is not keeping him in sinus
   (emailed cardiologist)
   - coumadin dose at 7.5
   - stop heparin gtt today
   .
   # Infiltrated IV site:  plastics said no compartment syndrome, appears
   stable
   -heating compresses, elevate above heart
   .

Summary:

The patient is a 76-year-old male admitted to the ICU with septic shock, presumed anoxic brain injury, post-op bacteremia, and cholecystitis. He has a history of seizures, atrial fibrillation, and diastolic heart failure. He was recently discharged from the hospital after undergoing aortic arch replacement, CABG, and repair of a dissected aorta. He was readmitted due to worsening septic shock and respiratory failure.

Current Status:

* Vital signs: T 38.1C, HR 65 bpm, BP 110/58 mmHg, RR 18 breaths/min, SpO2 100%
* Respiratory support: Tracheostomy tube, CPAP/PSV mode, PEEP 8 cmH2O, FiO2 40%
* Hemodynamic monitoring: Central venous catheter, arterial line
* Fluid balance: Total input 3,094 mL, total output 3,815 mL, with a negative balance of -721 mL
* Laboratory results: WBC 4.5 K/uL, Hct 25.7%, platelets 181 K/uL, creatinine 0.9 mg/dL, glucose 105 mg/dL
* Medications: Vancomycin, ciprofloxacin, furosemide, heparin, simvastatin, ASA, metoprolol, ranitidine

Potential Medical Complications:

1. Sepsis: The patient's septic shock is likely due to a combination of factors, including his recent surgical procedures, anoxic brain injury, and bacteremia.
2. Respiratory Failure: The patient's respiratory failure is likely secondary to his infectious process, and he may require continued respiratory support.
3. Acute Renal Failure: The patient's creatinine level has increased to 1.3 mg/dL, and he may require further management to prevent further renal damage.
4. Altered Mental Status: The patient's altered mental status may be due to his anoxic brain injury, hypotension, or oversedation from anti-epileptic medications.
5. Hematuria: The patient's hematuria may be due to anticoagulation in the setting of his foley catheter placement.
6. Anemia: The patient's anemia may be due to his recent blood transfusions and ongoing bleeding.
7. Cholecystitis: The patient's cholecystitis may be contributing to his septic picture, and he may require further management to prevent further complications.
8. Atrial Fibrillation: The patient's atrial fibrillation may be contributing to his tachycardia and hypotension.
9. UE DVTs: The patient's UE DVTs may be contributing to his hypotension and tachycardia.
10. Hyperlipidemia: The patient's hyperlipidemia may be contributing to his cardiovascular risk factors.

Plan:

* Continue antibiotics and antifungals as prescribed
* Monitor the patient's vital signs and laboratory results closely
* Continue respiratory support and hemodynamic monitoring
* Manage the patient's fluid balance and electrolytes
* Continue medications as prescribed, including anticoagulation therapy
* Monitor the patient's mental status and adjust sedation as needed
* Continue to manage the patient's hematuria and anemia
* Consider further management of the patient's cholecystitis
* Consider further management of the patient's atrial fibrillation and UE DVTs
* Monitor the patient's hyperlipidemia and adjust therapy as needed

   No CXR ordered for this AM
   Assessment and Plan
   76yo gentleman who is s/p redo replacement aortic arch with presumed
   anoxic brain injury and post-op bacteremia as well as cholecystitis s/p
   cholecystosomy admitted for sepsis, found to have serratia bacteremia.
   .
   .
   # Septic shock/ serratia: With serratia bacteremia, most likely source
   of sepsis is GI vs urine, although UA on admission was not impressive
   (although was after antibioitics).  LFTs were normal apart from alk
   phos, so cholecystitis less likely.  Could also be due to pneumonia or
   due to PICC line infection (PICC has been removed)
   - per ID, now on Vancomycin/Cipro: Day 1 [**12-3**] of Vanc and added Cipro
   [**12-4**].  If decompensates, Meropenem appropriate.  Plan to continue cipro
   x 3-4 weeks, vanco for 6 weeks (start [**11-14**])
   -hold next Vanc dose and check level in am
   - f/u culture urine, blood
   -try to avoid IVF as now volume overloaded
   -PICC today in IR
   -send new blood, urine, and sputum cx given new fever this AM
   -? Tap pleural effusion if fevers do not resolve after groin line
   pulled
   .
   # Respiratory Failure:  Likely secondary to infectious process.
   Empiric therapy for HAP as above. Was on trach mask at facility.
   Barriers to extubation currently include muscle weakness, altered
   mental status and pulmonary edema.
   - retry trache mask later today
   - Speech consult pending
   - Continue combivent
   - Continue gentle diuresis with Lasix as needed, goal I/O negative ~1L
   , eval in pm as already net negative 1L for day
   - PM I/O check
   .
   # Acute renal failure: increased to 1.3
   - follow urine output
   - renally dose meds (vancomycin)
   .
   # Altered mental status and h/o Seizures and Likely Anoxic Cerebral
   Injury:  No current evidence of seizure activity but he does have a
   history of non-convulsive status epilepticus.  EEG neg for seizure so
   likely due to hypotension, possibly oversedation from anti-epileptic
   medications.
   - appreciate neurology input; stopped Phenobarbital [**12-8**] with plan to
   cont Keppra and Dilantin.
   -Dilantin level today
   .
   # Hematuria and BPH:  Was described at rehab [**12-2**], now present.
   Patient was followed by urology during recent hospital stay and was
   started on flomax.  Continued to have some hematuria during this
   hospitalization, has 3 way foley and undergoing bladder irrigation.
   Likely due to anticoagulation in the setting of foley placements.  Now
   resolved.  If recurrs, might consider urology consult
   - cont flomax
   - continue Foley, no bladder irrigation currently needed
   .
   # Anemia:  Hct stable, had 1U yesterday of prbc.  Note that patient
   required multiple transfusions during recent hospital stay and he has
   guaiac positive stool as well as recent hematuria.
   - check Hct daily
   - active T&S
   - ranitidine for guaiac positive stool
   .
   # Recent Cholecystitis:   As above this may be contributing to the
   patient's septic picture.  Abdominal exam and LFTs somewhat
   reassuring.  Gen [**Doctor First Name 458**] states perc tube in place.
   -Per IR:  Pt needs cholangiogram to confirm that the cystic duct is
   patent and then has the tube capped.  At six weeks post insertion the
   patient typically has an elective cholecystectomy. The attending
   surgeon who was consulted at the time of the tube being inserted(Dr
   [**Last Name (STitle) **] should have the final say on future management however and I
   would suggest reconsulting her
   .
   # S/p Aortic arch repair/dissection/CABG:  Long, complicated course
   following the procedure.  CT surgery consulted in the ED.  Recently had
   TEE that did not show vegetations on grafts or pacemaker leads, but at
   risk for endovascular seeding, particularly if blood cultures come back
   positive.
   - follow any CT [**Doctor First Name 458**] recs
   - Continue simvastatin and ASA
   .
   # Elevated troponin and EKG changes: Suspect patient was somewhat
   ischemic in setting of hypotension and tachycardia.
   - continue ASA
   .
   # h/o diastolic heart failure:
   - Continue gentle diuresis as above
   .
   # Atrial Fibrillation and UE DVTs:  INR now 2.2, restarted home
   metoprolol.
   - consider stopping dronederone as this is not keeping him in sinus
   (emailed cardiologist)
   - coumadin dose at 7.5
   - stop heparin gtt today
   .
   # Infiltrated IV site:  plastics said no compartment syndrome, appears
   stable
   -heating compresses, elevate above heart
   .
   # Hyperlipidemia:  continue statin

Summary:

The patient is a 76-year-old male who was admitted to the ICU with septic shock, anoxic brain injury, and post-op bacteremia. He has a history of aortic arch replacement, CABG, and cholecystitis. He is currently receiving antibiotics, vasopressors, and diuretics to manage his septic shock. He has also been experiencing respiratory failure, acute renal failure, and altered mental status.

Potential Medical Complications:

1. Sepsis: The patient's septic shock may lead to further complications such as organ failure, disseminated intravascular coagulation, and death.
2. Respiratory Failure: The patient's respiratory failure may worsen, leading to further respiratory distress, pneumonia, and respiratory arrest.
3. Acute Renal Failure: The patient's acute renal failure may progress, leading to chronic kidney disease, electrolyte imbalances, and death.
4. Altered Mental Status: The patient's altered mental status may worsen, leading to further confusion, agitation, and increased risk of falls.
5. Anoxic Brain Injury: The patient's anoxic brain injury may lead to further neurologic deficits, including cognitive impairment, speech difficulties, and motor dysfunction.
6. Cholecystitis: The patient's cholecystitis may lead to further complications such as gangrene, perforation, and peritonitis.
7. Atrial Fibrillation: The patient's atrial fibrillation may lead to further complications such as stroke, heart failure, and cardiac arrest.
8. Deep Vein Thrombosis: The patient's deep vein thrombosis may lead to further complications such as pulmonary embolism, stroke, and death.
9. Infiltrated IV Site: The patient's infiltrated IV site may lead to further complications such as infection, abscess, and sepsis.

Based on the patient's condition and potential complications, it is essential to continue close monitoring and management to prevent further deterioration and improve outcomes.

Summary:

The patient is a 95.8 kg male admitted to the ICU with a history of seizures, hyperthyroidism, and allergy to amiodarone. He is currently receiving multiple medications, including antibiotics, anticonvulsants, and vasopressors. His vital signs are stable, with a heart rate of 65 bpm, blood pressure of 110/58 mmHg, and oxygen saturation of 100%. He is receiving mechanical ventilation with a CPAP/PSV mode, with a peak inspiratory pressure of 19 cmH2O and a positive end-expiratory pressure of 8 cmH2O.

The patient's laboratory results show mild anemia with a hemoglobin level of 9.6 g/dL, mild thrombocytopenia with a platelet count of 181 K/uL, and mild elevation in liver enzymes. His renal function is normal, with a creatinine level of 0.9 mg/dL.

Potential Medical Complications:

1. Seizure recurrence: The patient's history of seizures and current medication regimen make him at risk for recurrent seizures.
2. Infection: The patient is receiving antibiotics, but the possibility of infection cannot be ruled out.
3. Respiratory failure: The patient's respiratory status is stable, but the possibility of respiratory failure cannot be ruled out, especially with the patient's history of seizures and potential for respiratory muscle weakness.
4. Cardiac arrhythmias: The patient's history of hyperthyroidism and medication regimen make him at risk for cardiac arrhythmias.
5. Bleeding complications: The patient's thrombocytopenia and anticoagulant therapy make him at risk for bleeding complications.
6. Nutritional deficiencies: The patient's nutritional status is compromised, and he may require additional nutrition support to prevent deficiencies.
7. Gastrointestinal bleeding: The patient's history of seizures and potential for respiratory muscle weakness make him at risk for gastrointestinal bleeding.

Plan:

1. Monitor the patient's seizure activity and adjust medication as necessary.
2. Continue antibiotic therapy and monitor for signs of infection.
3. Continue mechanical ventilation and adjust settings as necessary to maintain adequate oxygenation and ventilation.
4. Monitor the patient's cardiac rhythm and adjust medication as necessary to prevent cardiac arrhythmias.
5. Monitor the patient's bleeding risk and adjust anticoagulant therapy as necessary.
6. Provide additional nutrition support as necessary to prevent nutritional deficiencies.
7. Monitor the patient's gastrointestinal status and adjust medication as necessary to prevent gastrointestinal bleeding.

Chief Complaint:
   24 Hour Events:
 MIDLINE - START [**2137-12-10**] 04:37 PM
 MULTI LUMEN - STOP [**2137-12-10**] 06:38 PM
   - Got midline instead of PICC line b/c couldn't get through his clot on
   either side
   - Started on a lasix gtt at 4:30pm @ 5mg/hr, increased throughout day
   but ended up at about 7mg/hr due to some relative hypotension
   - Urine lytes sent, FE urea 40 but wasn't oliguric so hard to
   interpret, had positive rare eos
   - Creatinine down to 1.5 in pm
   - Could consider tunneled catheter in this patient because needs access
   for 3.5 weeks or so
   - femoral line pulled
   - Had 4+ GNR on sputum gram stain
   - Neuro did not leave note
   - [**Doctor Last Name **] emailed back regarding chole tube.  Said:
   "Typically we do a cholangiogram through the tube to make sure that the
   cystic duct is patent, and if it is then cap the tube.  If the patient
   tolerates that we do an elective cholecystectomy at 6 weeks after
   placement.  HOWEVER, Mr. [**Known lastname 2149**] is a very, very poor candidate for any
   additional surgical procedure at this time or in the near future.
   If you really want the tube out at 6 weeks from insertion you can get a
   study through it to see if the cystic duct is patent, cap it to see if
   her tolerates the normal flow of bile and then simply take the tube out
   after tolerating having it capped and asymptomatic for 2 or more days.
   Simply keeping the tube in is not a problem, especially as it does let
   us know that his gallbladder is not the source of his sepsis (when he
   comes in the next time
.).  I think that management of the tube depends
   very much on his overall status."
   Allergies:
   Amiodarone
   hyperthryoidism
   Monosodium Glutamate
   violent headach
   Last dose of Antibiotics:
   Vancomycin - [**2137-12-8**] 08:05 PM
   Ciprofloxacin - [**2137-12-10**] 10:15 PM

   Famotidine 12. Furosemide 13. Heparin Flush (10 units/ml)
   14. Heparin 15. Heparin Flush (10 units/ml) 16. 17. Ipratropium Bromide
   MDI 18. LeVETiracetam 19. Lidocaine Jelly 2% (Urojet)
   20. Lorazepam 21. Metoprolol Tartrate 22. Nystatin Oral Suspension 23.
   OxycoDONE (Immediate Release)
   24. Phenytoin 25. Senna 26. Simvastatin 27. Sodium Chloride 0.9% Flush
   28. Sodium Chloride 0.9% Flush

Summary:

The patient is a 76-year-old gentleman who underwent redo replacement aortic arch with presumed anoxic brain injury and post-op bacteremia. He was admitted for sepsis, found to have Serratia bacteremia, and is currently in the ICU. The patient has multiple comorbidities, including atrial fibrillation, anemia, hyperlipidemia, and chronic heart failure. He has a history of seizures, anoxic cerebral injury, and aortic dissection.

The patient's current condition is as follows:

* Sepsis: He has Serratia bacteremia, and possible sources of infection include GU or GI, pneumonia, or PICC line infection.
* Respiratory failure: He is intubated and has a tracheostomy tube in place.
* Acute renal failure: His creatinine level is elevated, and he has received dye load on [**12-3**].
* Altered mental status: He has a history of seizures and anoxic cerebral injury, and is currently receiving anticonvulsant medications.
* Hypercalcemia: His calcium level is elevated, and he has a history of hyperthyroidism.
* Hematuria and BPH: He has a history of hematuria and BPH, and is currently undergoing bladder irrigation.
* Atrial fibrillation and UE DVTs: He has atrial fibrillation and UE DVTs, and is receiving anticoagulation therapy.
* Anemia: He has anemia, and has received multiple transfusions during his recent hospital stay.

Potential medical complications:

1. Sepsis: The patient is at risk for further sepsis and organ dysfunction due to his bacteremia and underlying comorbidities.
2. Respiratory failure: The patient is intubated and at risk for further respiratory failure due to his underlying lung disease and sepsis.
3. Acute renal failure: The patient's creatinine level is elevated, and he is at risk for further kidney damage due to his sepsis and underlying comorbidities.
4. Altered mental status: The patient has a history of seizures and anoxic cerebral injury, and is at risk for further neurological decline due to his underlying comorbidities and medications.
5. Hypercalcemia: The patient's calcium level is elevated, and he is at risk for further hypercalcemia due to his underlying comorbidities and medications.
6. Hematuria and BPH: The patient has a history of hematuria and BPH, and is at risk for further complications due to his underlying comorbidities and medications.
7. Atrial fibrillation and UE DVTs: The patient has atrial fibrillation and UE DVTs, and is at risk for further complications due to his underlying comorbidities and medications.
8. Anemia: The patient has anemia, and is at risk for further complications due to his underlying comorbidities and medications.

Recommendations:

1. Continue to monitor the patient's vital signs and laboratory values closely.
2. Continue to treat the patient's sepsis with antibiotics and supportive care.
3. Consider further diagnostic testing to determine the source of the patient's sepsis and to rule out other potential complications.
4. Continue to manage the patient's respiratory failure with mechanical ventilation and other supportive care.
5. Consider further diagnostic testing to determine the cause of the patient's acute renal failure and to rule out other potential complications.
6. Continue to manage the patient's altered mental status with anticonvulsant medications and other supportive care.

8. Continue to manage the patient's hematuria and BPH with bladder irrigation and other supportive care.
9. Continue to manage the patient's atrial fibrillation and UE DVTs with anticoagulation therapy and other supportive care.
10. Consider further diagnostic testing to determine the cause of the patient's anemia and to rule out other potential complications.

Overall, the patient is at high risk for further complications due to his underlying comorbidities and medications. Close monitoring and aggressive management are necessary to prevent further deterioration and to improve the patient's outcomes.

   76yo gentleman who is s/p redo replacement aortic arch with presumed
   anoxic brain injury and post-op bacteremia as well as cholecystitis s/p
   cholecystosomy admitted for sepsis, found to have serratia bacteremia.
   # Sepsis: Found to have serratia bacteremia on OSH culture. Possible
   sources include GU or GI. LFTs were normal apart from alk phos, so
   cholecystitis less likely.  Could also be due to pneumonia or due to
   PICC line infection (PICC has been removed).
   Sputum with GNR on [**12-10**].
   - per ID: Vancomycin/Cipro: Day 1 [**12-3**] of Vanc and added Cipro [**12-4**].
   If decompensates, Meropenem appropriate.  Plan to continue cipro x [**3-6**]
   weeks, vanco for 6 weeks (start [**11-14**])
   - f/u culture blood, sputum
   -try to avoid IVF as now volume overloaded
   # Fever: Most likely source is femoral CVL.  Pullled on [**12-10**].  Other
   possible sources of infection include pulmonary effusion, urinary (pt
   with recent bladder irrigation and GU manipulation).  No leukocytosis
   currently.
   - consider CT-guided thoracentesis if fevers continue after femoral
   line pulled or patient decompensates
   # Respiratory Failure:  Likely secondary to infectious process.
   Empiric therapy for HAP as above. Was on trach mask at facility.
   Barriers to extubation currently include muscle weakness and pulmonary
   edema.  Now on [**5-10**].
   - retry trache mask later today
   - Speech consult pending
   - Continue combivent
   - Lasix drip today for goal of 1 L neg today; BP cannot tolerate bolus
   dosing for diuresis.  Decrease some this am given elevated creatinine
   - PM I/O check
   # Acute renal failure: increased to 1.6 today, possibly related to
   recent dye load on [**12-3**], although this would be a late presentation.
   Possibly also component of ATN from episodes of hypotension.
   - follow urine output
   - renally dose meds (vancomycin)
   # Altered mental status and h/o Seizures and Likely Anoxic Cerebral
   Injury:  No current evidence of seizure activity but he does have a
   history of non-convulsive status epilepticus.  EEG neg for seizure so
   likely due to hypotension, possibly oversedation from anti-epileptic
   medications.  Now improved.
   - appreciate neurology input; stopped Phenobarbital [**12-8**] with plan to
   cont Keppra and Dilantin.
   - Dilantin level today is pending; Will touch base with neurology and
   repeat level tomorrow.
   # Hypercalcemia: New finding yesterday, corrected Ca [**38**].9.
   -check PTH
   # Hematuria and BPH:  Was described at rehab [**12-2**]/  Patient was
   followed by urology during recent hospital stay and was started on
   flomax.  Continued to have some hematuria during this hospitalization,
   has 3 way foley and undergoing bladder irrigation.  Likely due to
   anticoagulation in the setting of foley placements.  Now resolved.  If
   recurrs, might consider urology consult
   - continue Foley, no bladder irrigation currently needed

   - consider stopping dronederone as this is not keeping him in sinus
   (emailed cardiologist)
   - coumadin dose at 7.5
   - stop heparin gtt when therapeutic x 48 hrs

   he has guaiac positive stool as well as recent hematuria.
   - check Hct daily

   # Recent Cholecystitis:   As above this may be contributing to the
   patient's septic picture.  Abdominal exam and LFTs somewhat

   Per Dr. [**Last Name (STitle) **]
the tube in is not a problem, especially as it does
   let us know that his gallbladder is not the source of his sepsis (when

.).  I think that management of the tube

Summary:

The patient is a 76-year-old male admitted to the ICU with severe sepsis, respiratory failure, acute kidney injury, and altered mental status. He has a complex medical history, including a recent redo aortic arch repair, anoxic brain injury, and a history of seizures. He was found to have Serratia bacteremia and has been treated with vancomycin and ciprofloxacin. His current medications include furosemide, heparin, and metoprolol.

Potential Medical Complications:

1. Sepsis: The patient's sepsis is likely to continue to be a significant concern, and he may require ongoing antibiotic therapy and supportive care.
2. Respiratory Failure: The patient's respiratory failure is likely to persist, and he may require ongoing mechanical ventilation and oxygen therapy.
3. Acute Kidney Injury: The patient's acute kidney injury is likely to continue to be a concern, and he may require ongoing fluid management and close monitoring of his kidney function.
4. Altered Mental Status: The patient's altered mental status is likely to continue to be a concern, and he may require ongoing monitoring and management of his neurological status.
5. Hypercalcemia: The patient's hypercalcemia is a new finding and may require further evaluation and management.
6. Hematuria and BPH: The patient's hematuria and BPH may require ongoing management and monitoring.
7. Atrial Fibrillation and UE DVTs: The patient's atrial fibrillation and UE DVTs may require ongoing management and monitoring.
8. Anemia: The patient's anemia may require ongoing management and monitoring.
9. Recent Cholecystitis: The patient's recent cholecystitis may require ongoing management and monitoring.
10. S/p Aortic arch repair/dissection/CABG: The patient's recent surgical procedure may require ongoing management and monitoring.

Recommendations:

1. Continue to monitor the patient's sepsis and adjust antibiotic therapy as necessary.
2. Continue to provide mechanical ventilation and oxygen therapy to support the patient's respiratory function.
3. Continue to manage the patient's acute kidney injury with fluid management and close monitoring of his kidney function.
4. Continue to monitor the patient's altered mental status and adjust his neurological management as necessary.
5. Further evaluate and manage the patient's hypercalcemia.
6. Continue to manage the patient's hematuria and BPH.
7. Continue to manage the patient's atrial fibrillation and UE DVTs.
8. Continue to manage the patient's anemia.
9. Continue to manage the patient's recent cholecystitis.
10. Continue to manage the patient's recent surgical procedure and adjust his care plan as necessary.

   76yo gentleman who is s/p redo replacement aortic arch with presumed
   anoxic brain injury and post-op bacteremia as well as cholecystitis s/p
   cholecystosomy admitted for sepsis, found to have serratia bacteremia.
   .
   .
   # Sepsis: Found to have serratia bacteremia on OSH culture. Possible
   sources include GU or GI. LFTs were normal apart from alk phos, so
   cholecystitis less likely.  Could also be due to pneumonia or due to
   PICC line infection (PICC has been removed).
   Sputum with GNR, coverered with Cipro.
   - per ID: Vancomycin/Cipro: Day 1 [**12-3**] of Vanc and added Cipro [**12-4**].
   If decompensates, Meropenem appropriate.  Plan to continue cipro x [**3-6**]
   weeks, vanco for 6 weeks (start [**11-14**])
   - f/u culture blood, sputum
   -try to avoid IVF as now volume overloaded
   .
   # Fever: Most likely source is femoral CVL.  Plan to pull line and
   reassess.  Other possible sources of infection include pulmonary
   effusion, urinary (pt with recent bladder irrigation and GU
   manipulation).  No leukocytosis currently.
   - consider CT-guided thoracentesis if fevers continue after femoral
   line pulled or patient decompensates
   .
   # Respiratory Failure:  Likely secondary to infectious process.
   Empiric therapy for HAP as above. Was on trach mask at facility.
   Barriers to extubation currently include muscle weakness, altered
   mental status and pulmonary edema.  Now on [**5-10**].
   - retry trache mask later today
   - Speech consult pending
   - Continue combivent
   - Lasix drip today for goal of 1 L neg today; BP cannot tolerate bolus
   dosing for diuresis.  Decrease some this am given elevated creatinine
   - PM I/O check
   .
   # Acute renal failure: increased to 1.6 today, possibly related to
   recent dye load on [**12-3**], although this would be a late presentation.
   Possibly also component of ATN from episodes of hypotension.
   - follow urine output
   - spin urine sediment
   - renally dose meds (vancomycin)
   .
   # Altered mental status and h/o Seizures and Likely Anoxic Cerebral
   Injury:  No current evidence of seizure activity but he does have a
   history of non-convulsive status epilepticus.  EEG neg for seizure so
   likely due to hypotension, possibly oversedation from anti-epileptic
   medications.
   - appreciate neurology input; stopped Phenobarbital [**12-8**] with plan to
   cont Keppra and Dilantin.
   - Dilantin level today is low; possibly dosing altered from stopping
   phenobarbital?  Will touch base with neurology and repeat level
   tomorrow.
   .
   # Hypercalcemia: New finding today, corrected Ca [**38**].9.  Will monitor
   for now and consider PTH tomorrow if persists.
   # Hematuria and BPH:  Was described at rehab [**12-2**], now present.
   Patient was followed by urology during recent hospital stay and was
   started on flomax.  Continued to have some hematuria during this
   hospitalization, has 3 way foley and undergoing bladder irrigation.
   Likely due to anticoagulation in the setting of foley placements.  Now
   resolved.  If recurrs, might consider urology consult
   - continue Foley, no bladder irrigation currently needed
   .
   # Atrial Fibrillation and UE DVTs:  INR now 2.2, restarted home
   metoprolol.
   - consider stopping dronederone as this is not keeping him in sinus
   (emailed cardiologist)
   - coumadin dose at 7.5
   - stop heparin gtt when therapeutic x 48 hrs
   # Anemia:  Hct stable, had 1U yesterday of prbc.  Note that patient
   required multiple transfusions during recent hospital stay and he has
   guaiac positive stool as well as recent hematuria.
   - check Hct daily
   - active T&S
   - ranitidine for guaiac positive stool
   .
   # Recent Cholecystitis:   As above this may be contributing to the
   patient's septic picture.  Abdominal exam and LFTs somewhat
   reassuring.  Gen [**Doctor First Name 458**] states perc tube in place.
   -Per IR:  Pt needs cholangiogram to confirm that the cystic duct is
   patent and then has the tube capped.  At six weeks post insertion the
   patient typically has an elective cholecystectomy. The attending
   surgeon who was consulted at the time of the tube being inserted(Dr
   [**Last Name (STitle) **] should have the final say on future management
   - reconsult Dr. [**Last Name (STitle) **]
   .
   # S/p Aortic arch repair/dissection/CABG:  Long, complicated course
   following the procedure.  CT surgery consulted in the ED.  Recently had
   TEE that did not show vegetations on grafts or pacemaker leads, but at
   risk for endovascular seeding, particularly if blood cultures come back
   positive.
   - follow any CT [**Doctor First Name 458**] recs
   - Continue simvastatin and ASA
   .
   # h/o diastolic heart failure:
   - Continue gentle diuresis as above
   .
   .
   # Infiltrated IV site:  plastics said no compartment syndrome, appears
   stable
   -heating compresses, elevate above heart
   .
   # Hyperlipidemia:  continue statin

   - follow urine output
   - spin urine sediment
   - renally dose meds (vancomycin)
   .
   # Altered mental status and h/o Seizures and Likely Anoxic Cerebral
   Injury:  No current evidence of seizure activity but he does have a
   history of non-convulsive status epilepticus.  EEG neg for seizure so
   likely due to hypotension, possibly oversedation from anti-epileptic
   medications.
   - appreciate neurology input; stopped Phenobarbital [**12-8**] with plan to
   cont Keppra and Dilantin.
   - Dilantin level today is low; possibly dosing altered from stopping
   phenobarbital?  Will touch base with neurology and repeat level
   tomorrow.
   .
   # Hypercalcemia: New finding today, corrected Ca [**38**].9.  Will monitor
   for now and consider PTH tomorrow if persists.
   # Hematuria and BPH:  Was described at rehab [**12-2**], now present.
   Patient was followed by urology during recent hospital stay and was
   started on flomax.  Continued to have some hematuria during this
   hospitalization, has 3 way foley and undergoing bladder irrigation.
   Likely due to anticoagulation in the setting of foley placements.  Now
   resolved.  If recurrs, might consider urology consult
   - continue Foley, no bladder irrigation currently needed
   .
   # Atrial Fibrillation and UE DVTs:  INR now 2.2, restarted home
   metoprolol.
   - consider stopping dronederone as this is not keeping him in sinus
   (emailed cardiologist)
   - coumadin dose at 7.5
   - stop heparin gtt when therapeutic x 48 hrs
   # Anemia:  Hct stable, had 1U yesterday of prbc.  Note that patient
   required multiple transfusions during recent hospital stay and he has
   guaiac positive stool as well as recent hematuria.
   - check Hct daily
   - active T&S
   - ranitidine for guaiac positive stool
   .
   # Recent Cholecystitis:   As above this may be contributing to the
   patient's septic picture.  Abdominal exam and LFTs somewhat
   reassuring.  Gen [**Doctor First Name 458**] states perc tube in place.
   -Per IR:  Pt needs cholangiogram to confirm that the cystic duct is
   patent and then has the tube capped.  At six weeks post insertion the
   patient typically has an elective cholecystectomy. The attending
   surgeon who was consulted at the time of the tube being inserted(Dr
   [**Last Name (STitle) **] should have the final say on future management
   - reconsult Dr. [**Last Name (STitle) **]
   .
   # S/p Aortic arch repair/dissection/CABG:  Long, complicated course
   following the procedure.  CT surgery consulted in the ED.  Recently had
   TEE that did not show vegetations on grafts or pacemaker leads, but at
   risk for endovascular seeding, particularly if blood cultures come back
   positive.
   - follow any CT [**Doctor First Name 458**] recs
   - Continue simvastatin and ASA
   .
   # h/o diastolic heart failure:
   - Continue gentle diuresis as above
   .
   .
   # Infiltrated IV site:  plastics said no compartment syndrome, appears
   stable
   -heating compresses, elevate above heart
   .

Summary:

The patient is a 76-year-old gentleman who underwent redo replacement aortic arch with presumed anoxic brain injury and post-op bacteremia. He was admitted for sepsis and was found to have Serratia bacteremia. He has a complex medical history, including chronic heart failure, atrial fibrillation, anemia, and hyperlipidemia. He is currently in the ICU with respiratory failure, acute kidney injury, and altered mental status.

Potential Medical Complications:

1. Sepsis: The patient has a high risk of developing septic shock due to his bacteremia and underlying medical conditions.
2. Respiratory Failure: The patient's respiratory failure is likely secondary to his infectious process and may require continued mechanical ventilation.
3. Acute Kidney Injury: The patient's acute kidney injury is likely related to his recent dye load and may require continued renal replacement therapy.
4. Altered Mental Status: The patient's altered mental status is likely due to his sepsis, anoxic brain injury, and possible oversedation from anti-epileptic medications.
5. Hypercalcemia: The patient's new finding of hypercalcemia requires close monitoring and may require treatment to prevent further complications.
6. Hematuria and BPH: The patient's hematuria and BPH may require further evaluation and treatment to prevent further complications.
7. Atrial Fibrillation and UE DVTs: The patient's atrial fibrillation and UE DVTs require continued anticoagulation therapy and monitoring.
8. Anemia: The patient's anemia requires continued transfusion support and may require further evaluation to determine the underlying cause.
9. Recent Cholecystitis: The patient's recent cholecystitis may require further evaluation and treatment to prevent further complications.
10. S/p Aortic Arch Repair/Dissection/CABG: The patient's complex surgical history requires continued monitoring and may require further evaluation and treatment to prevent further complications.

Overall, the patient requires close monitoring and management of his complex medical conditions to prevent further complications and improve his chances of recovery.
